segments.text: Colonel Wilcox, I'd like you to start off just telling me a little bit about your military history.
And I guess it began with the Aggie Corps?
Right.
I graduated from Curran High School here in Galveston in 54 and went to Texas A&M and graduated from Texas A&M in 1958 with a degree in marketing and insurance and
Also at that time, I was in the Corps of Cadets, and I became a second lieutenant of infantry upon graduation, and then went to Fort Benning, Georgia for the basic officer's course.
Okay.
Now to start talking about exactly what you did in Vietnam.
On your first tour, could you describe briefly your responsibilities and position in your first tour?
Okay.
The first time I was over there was April of 1967.
through April of 1968, which was part of the Tet Offensive of 1968 in Vietnam.
The first time I was an advisor to a Arvin battalion, a senior advisor to a battalion.
It was myself and a sergeant.
And we two was the entire American forces with about 2,500 men
Battalion, which had the responsibility to guard a American and Vietnamese Air Force Base, which was called Tan Son Nuc.
Tan Son Nuc Air Force Base was in or outside of Saigon.
Also, this battalion, a Vietnamese battalion, was responsible for not only guarding this outer belt of the Tan Son Nuc Air Force Base, but it had the responsibility to guard the training center
which was located in the area on the outer belt of the Air Force Base.
This training center does the same thing as an American training center does.
It trains individuals in about eight weeks from a ROAR recruit to a fighting soldier that goes out and takes his place in a normal battalion.
ROAR goes on to some advanced training such as the airborne
Ranger-type training.
My job there was to be an advisor, only advisor, to the battalion commander that was in charge of the security for that area.
And I had no role in command.
As advisor, our sole purpose was to try to advise the Vietnamese counterpart, in this case he was a major and I was also at that time, on some of the
tactics to be successful.
Also, we were available since we had American units backing us up from the standpoint that we were in communication with American units.

We could call upon American artillery fire with his approval, and we could call upon American gunships to come in, which are helicopters, to come in and support us if they were available and if he wanted them after
We were nicely trying to talk him into using these things.
So we were there to provide advice and also to provide fire support to him if he wanted to.
As a senior advisor to the Army Battalion at Saigon, what types of fighting tactics were taught?
Well, our battalion, and I say our because I felt like I was a part of the battalion, we were a security unit, and we put out patrols at night.

up patrols during the day to ambush any infiltrators that may be coming in also to provide security at the main intersections within the training site training site was about two and a half miles oh about two and a half miles wide maybe about three miles long it covered a live fire training range and some of the tactical

maneuver training grounds that they had out there and for the most part everything was done to provide security to keep the Viet Cong which were somewhere in the area or the North Vietnamese regular battalions out of the area so they wouldn't attack the train training outfits while they were trying to train and then I say we also had an additional mission
to provide security for the American-Vietnamese Air Force Base, which was located in Saigon and Tanzania.
Okay.

What exactly was the difference, I was just wondering, the official relationship between this earlier phase of the war when we were advisors, you were an advisor, and to later when they were commanders?
Well, this goes back, oh, in around the 60s, 60 to 62 or so.

when the Americans went in under the auspices of a military advisory group and we in fact only advised and did not in fact get into combat we went with them we were not supposed to fire at that time but that wasn't the situation when I was there when I was there we had advisors who protected themselves and
were in combat but were advisors.
But we also had regular American units that were there fighting.
In my case, on this first tour, I was there as an advisor.
I did fire when I was fired upon.
An officer who's trying to advise can't really get into the front line tactics and act as a rifleman when he's back there with the commander trying to advise from an advantage point.
The second time when I went over this area, I was with an American battalion, or actually American Division 101st Airborne, which was in fact engaged with the enemy, and we weren't advising anybody.
We were just fighting.
Why do the Arvin troops need such intense training in light of their familiarity with their own country and the grill of fighting that they've been associated with since the 1930s?
Again, I'm going to have to give you some of my opinions on it.
From what I could see, the orphan battalions were not well equipped.
When I was there in 67, when I first got there, they had a lot of old, obsolete arms.
You're probably not familiar with what I'm going to say, but back, oh, about 1950s, we had in our training sites what we called water-cooled machine guns.
which was a five-gallon can of water attached to a rubber hose that cooled the machine gun down so it would not burn the barrels up when you fired them on a training range.
They had these weapons in actual combat.
The Americans had washed them out of their system 10, 15, 20 years before that.
They had a lot of old World War II arms, carbines that the Americans were not using at all.
Our government was trying to upgrade

their weaponry with the new m16 rifles the automatic rifles and we were sent in to advise them how to use these weapons and i would say we were there to try to teach them how to do it the american way even though we a lot of talk was said that well we were just trying to help them and advance their training we were really in fact trying to show them how to do it the american way so that
We thought our way was the best.
How did the tradition of the Arvin families following their husbands into combat locations affect their attitudes?
I didn't see too much of that.
The battalion I was with worked out of a location.
We did not really move from that area.
We had the responsibility for, I say, the outer belt of the Tonsenuk.
We had the responsibility for the training center.
And we didn't go from place to place to place like some other battalions did.
The family was there.
And I might digress a second here.
I knew a major who was in the Vietnamese Army who was other than the one I was advising.
And we talked about sometimes on Sunday afternoons, you would think that there was no war going on at all, that they would be in civilian clothes.
And it would seem like that nobody would attack us or we wouldn't attack anybody on Sundays.
I'm talking when I was with the Army Battalion now, Republic of Vietnam.
And they said, well, you know, you people come over here, I mean Americans, and you fight for a year and you go home to your family.
He said, we live this day in and day out, seven days a week.
So on Sunday afternoons, if we don't have any problems, then we kind of relax.
And it was kind of an unwritten law that the,
Sunday afternoons, it was pretty peaceful.
How significant was, although this may not apply to your position now, but how significant was Arvin's desertion in combat?
How committed were the men in training?
Well, I felt that the training that they received was as good as the people they had trained them.
That if you had a good, strong commander,
who was really pushing at him and getting the job done, then the soldiers under him were doing the same thing.
You have to kind of look at how the Vietnamese Army recruited.
Much different than the recruitment of the American Army.
In the American Army, you'll be called up or you'll go down and volunteer and say, I want to join.
But in the Vietnamese Army, that's not the way it works.
Not all the time.
They'll run a patrol.

down through a town and any individual they catch who fits between a certain age bracket that particular day they will put in a two and a half ton truck which is a truck they use and bring one out to training i mean they they might be going to church and lo and behold their next day they're training at a training center and their family is left and don't know what happened to them or anything else until they finally write them and say hey i just got drafted so they had a very peculiar way of
drafting by just going out and grabbing me off the street.
And in some cases, and we've done it in our army too, unwritten I guess, a guy gets in trouble with the police and the police says, well, we won't press charges if you go down and enlist.
So the guy goes down and enlists so he doesn't go to jail or do other things.
And this has happened a few times you've probably heard about in our own army.
Now I'd like to turn the interview over to the Tet Offensive in 1968.
You're a very prominent part of this since you were an actual observer.
Maybe you could describe the events of the day, the day of the attack on Saigon.
What were your initial thoughts when it occurred?
Well, I had just got back from R&R.
Actually, R&R is Arrest and Recuperation.
The American forces were given six days.
Let me think now.
I think it was two weeks, I'm sorry.
And at that time, you could travel anywhere you wanted.
So I went to Hawaii and got back about two weeks before the Tet Offensive.
And it was kind of peaceful and quiet.
And I had sat down and talked with my counterpart, which we called our individual we were giving advice to.
And my sergeant was there.
And we had gone over a few things which could have happened.
And generally, the attacks, every year is Tet.
They have this ceremony every year.
And every year, you generally didn't have too much problem where we were.
We were in Saigon, which was the capital of Vietnam at that time.
And people generally would have their wars out in the rice farms areas.
And Saigon would generally be pretty quiet, and nobody would bother anybody.
Maybe there's a few shootings on the street, but
Otherwise, it was kind of a quiet, peaceful area.

So we had been talking about it, and the Viennese commander I talked to had decided that he felt, based on reports that he was receiving through his intelligence, that there may be some kind of offensive in the Saigon area.
So he wasn't going to put as many troops out on vacation.
And Tet offensive, I mean, Tet is

like christmas for us so he decided he wasn't going to put as many out and that the training center commander and you remember we were talking about two different people we're a security force for a training center but we also had a general guinea general that was in charge of the training center and so they decided they weren't going to put as many people on vacation to include the trainees

uh as they had before because they felt that something was going to happen how they got this source i don't really know because i wasn't getting that much source from my own american side of the house they felt yeah there's going to be something going on but they didn't expect what we'd get into from the standpoint of i didn't know about what we were going to get into i don't know if anybody else did but so we were ready somewhat for what was going on we had plenty of ammunition we'd all always been pretty well
prepared for anything because the VC, now VC is an individual who is a civilian by day and a soldier by night.
He's not really a North Vietnamese Viet Cong type.
He's a South Vietnamese soldier for the North Vietnam.
You understand all that?
So he's, we fell through some sources and we had been picking up information.
We've been picking up some caches of arms
that something was going to happen.
Didn't know how big it was going to be.
So we had reinforced a lot of areas where there were main routes in the area.
We had two main highways leading in to Saigon that came right through our training center, which was one was Highway 13 and Highway 1.
And we had already built long ago brick strongholds or pillboxes, if you want to call it that,
and we'd already had these things with sandbags and what have you.
So we put more ammunition in.
We put additional firepower.
We were using .50 caliber machine guns we put in there.

We had put in, and this is all Vietnamese stuff, and I say when I say we, they, had beefed it up, put additional personnel, tried to improve some of the communications to them so we knew what was going on.
And the Knight of Tet,
We kind of lucked out.
The first round that they fired on us was a RKG round, which is something like a bazooka round.
And they fired that at the main bunker leading through Highway 13, I believe it was.
And the rocket hit a cement pillar instead of hitting the bunker.
Now, these RPGs they used could go through a tank.
It hit the bunker...
a pillow, which is a cement pillow, to the side of the bunker, not the bunker itself, which pretty well got everybody awake when those things hit.

They then saw, they, meaning the South Vietnamese, saw where the round had came from, so they fired back a 50-caliber machine gun and what have you, and it was down a kind of a ditch-like on the side of the road.
And they had caught the VCs and, in this case, North Vietnamese soldiers by surprise.

and uh well we had three days of good fighting that time i say good fighting i mean real close in fighting we killed 97 of them and captured about three truckloads of equipment and we lost seven of our own uh no americans but just seven of our own now this is just our battalion other things are going on around us in other zones that was unbelievable but uh
I think for the response that we had from this particular bunker area and them missing the bunker area with the first shot really kind of turned the tide for us.
Did you consider it an American victory at the time?
You mean of our little thing going on there or just the whole Tet offensive?
Right, the whole Tet, I think.
It's hard for me to say American victory because I was working with the Vietnamese.
I felt they did a real good job in repulsing the attacks.
We had lost a lot when they got in.
Everybody was shaking their heads how they could infiltrate and get into Saigon.
The roads were always being checked.
Buses and what have you were being checked, and different types of trucks and what have you being checked.
But when this offensive took effect, it seems like the North Vietnamese and the VCs were everywhere, behind us, around us, front of us, left and right.
And a lot of questions were asked.
I know General Westmoreland, the American general, had a lot of questions for his staff on how could all these people get in to Saigon without somebody finding out about it.
And I don't know if that was ever answered.
But I personally didn't think it was a victory from the standpoint of them getting in.
I thought it was a victory from the standpoint of us repulsing them after they had got in.
But no, I think we should have had better security, both American and Vietnamese side, so that they wouldn't have got in to start with.
Even though we still, well,
We killed so many of the Viet Cong, almost 15,000.
Do you see it as a psychological victory for the enemy?
Psychological victory for the enemy.
Well, no, not really.
I feel really that, in personal opinion again, not any official government opinion, but my opinion, is that
We really didn't win a thing.
We went over there, we fought, we bombed, we advised.
But when you do this and you don't go to the source of the problem, in the early stages of the war, we could not cross over to Cambodia and fight.
We could not bomb in Cambodia.
We could not fire across the border in Cambodia because we were more than given the authority by our government or whatever president might be in power at that time

uh you couldn't carry the war to north vietnam nobody wanted to go across from south to north and attack them we wasn't bombing north vietnam they were using ho chi minh trail to bring equipment down then some of our presidents decide well yes okay let's go ahead and do that we did that my personal opinion is that if we wanted to end that war we could have won it and ended in 30 days by turning loose the united states air force
the Strategic Air Command or any of the other big powers that we have and wipe North Vietnam off the map if we wanted to.
But again here, I'm sure that people higher than I was was concerned that if we did take North Vietnam out or Red China, we would have probably got into a bigger, more wider-scale war.
And I think they were reallywe were really putting out brush fires when the
the Red Chinese and the North Vietnamese were kind of sitting back and not getting the full brunt of anything.
We were fighting in South Vietnam for quite a long time.

Our presence then, yeah, okay, did decide, and I think the 101st went in, and I'm not sure of this, and the 1st Division went across the border into Cambodia, and we did do some bombing in the north, quite a bit of bombing if you're
seen James Fonder's stories.
But then we didn't continue with it.
We did it for a while, and the public opinion got upset, and all those other things went on.
We stopped, and they built back up again, and here we were fighting in the South again.
How did the military measure progress?
Which one?
The New Year's of the Americans.
Well, I think the only progress you could see was your daily reports of the ratio between how many we killed and how many we got killed.
The Vietnamese War or the war at that time, whether you were in Cambodia or North Vietnam, wherever it may be that they were fighting at, there was no front lines like in World War II.
You couldn't measure on the ground.
One day you might own it, that night he owns it.
There was nothing that could say, okay, on this parallel, 38th parallel, this is all ours behind us and that's all theirs in front.

The only thing you could really measure in is how much equipment you captured, how much you blew up, how many people you killed, how many people you lost, that you got wounded, that you got your own people that got killed.
Not necessarily this time, but any time during your tours, were you aware of the so-called statistical juggling in body counts, kill ratios, and lost equipment?
No, I never heard anything about that until after I got back from Vietnam, even the second time.
I do know that we reported everything that we killed.
We may have not reported everything that we had captured.

uh we kept some of the stuff back for ourselves everything that that you capture uh had to be turned in and in some cases we captured american equipment and we decided that the no use report in american equipment we captured because we can use it ourselves and equipment was very hard to get and if we got american radio or or something that that we could use we didn't report it being
captured because every time you reported something being captured, somebody in Saigon on the Vietnamese side of the house wanted you to turn it in so there's something more that you've done.
So we never turned in anything that was American that we could use.
We just told them what we didn't want to have.
You couldn't keep any of the captured equipment yourself, supposedly.
Again, talking about the training, was the U.S. Army training Arvin in American tactics?
or in guerrilla warfare?

The units that I were with, we were training them as infantrymen, I would say American standards, because I'd been a training commander of units in the United States, and we tailored the training to fighting in the jungle, but most of the training that we were doing was, I felt, the American way of doing things.
Now, I'm saying this because I was with an infantry training unit.
Now, there were other units in Vietnam, American Ranger units, American Special Forces, which were doing their style of training with Vietnamese units.
And sure, they trained them as Rangers and guerrilla warfare and what have you.
But my people that we were training were straight infantry, and we were training as infantry.
using a combination of firepower and maneuver, and kind of tailored that to the jungle-type warfare.
Okay.
What was the American morale like at this time during Tet, throughout the ranks?
Well, again, that's hard for me to say what the overall American morale was, because
Again, I was only one of me and one sergeant, and he was a senior sergeant.
He was an E-8, which is the second highest sergeant that you can have in the Army.
And our morale was good.
We were very pleased with what we were doing.
We felt we were winning.
I really couldn't tell you what the morale of the other American units, because we didn't get to see too many American units in that time.
I guess because we had done real well.
I feel that we'd done real well pushing them out of Saigon and areas that the morale must have been high.
I never heard anybody say it wasn't, but again, I didn't see it myself.
It was just me and the other Viennese.
As far as I'm concerned, our morale was high because we were doing pretty good.
Did Tet prove anything to you at the time about the determination of the North Vietnamese

Yeah, I felt that they really tried, the North Vietnamese, really tried to put a black eye on the American-South Vietnamese relationship, and I think they really underestimated the will of the South Vietnamese at that time.
I really felt that South Vietnamese and the American unit
And I say American units.
We also had over there other units from other countries.
We had the Korean White Horse Division, which was a very strong division, and you had other countries involved.
I think they underestimated the combined firepower of the Americans and other Allied forces over there.
I thought we were doing real well in 1068.
Okay.
Not specifically with your first tour or just anything.
Looking back at Vietnam, I'd like to see if you could evaluate military personnel.
Did you ever feel the military was top-heavy in Vietnam?
Well, when you talk about top-heavy, you're talking about senior officers.
I didn't feel that way.
I've heard stories about it, but again, here, what I personally saw...
We were generally short personnel.

I did notice, though, and you talk to any infantry soldier on the ground, that if you had a pretty good battle going on and you had a couple battalions involved, you had a whole bunch of helicopters flying around and you would have either a battalion commander and division commanders and a bunch of staff officers.
Everybody would want to go see what's going on.
And you would have more helicopters flying around of higher ranking people watching the show.
And everybody's trying to give the infantry command on the ground guidance on how to do it.
And you didn't lack for anybody telling you what they thought when you had something going on.
But I wouldn't say it was top heavy, but you had so many different groups over there.
You had your division people, and you had your staff people, and you had regional people.
I served in Korea twice, not during time of war, and you had all different types of groups over there, too.
You had your combined staff, and you had your American staff, the United Nations staff.
By the time you get all these staffs, same thing in Vietnam, by the time you had all these staffs of people, you had a lot of people running around.
Recently, I read a book by Philip Caputo called The Rumor of War.
And he was talking about a problem with fragging of officers, unexplained deaths.
Have you ever heard of evidence of that?
Yeah.
Not my first tour.
I wasn't with any Americans to speak of.
But my second time in 101st Airborne, they've had that.
I think you might remember a Life magazine article that came out where
a West Point officer, for that matter, had decided not to go on a mission because they took a vote among the soldiers of that company and decided they weren't going to go on a mission.
That's unheard of, not only a West Point officer, but unheard of any officer that would take a vote in a unit to find out they were going on a mission.
The military is democratic, but not that democratic.
But, yeah, I heard of it, I think,
At that time, when I was in 101st, there was a court-martial going on where some soldier threw a grenade into one of his company commander's tents.
There was a lot of drugs wrapped up into it, too.
Drugs in Vietnam.
And I was over there the second time in 1970, in 101st Airborne.
Drugs were pretty easy to get.
The North Vietnamese made available
drugs at no cost.
The soldier wanted to get drugs and the commander wasn't really checking it.
It was awful hard.
We had urinalysis tests and everything else.
Drugs were readily available and if they wanted it, they got it.
It was awful hard to control.
What impact do you feel that the short rotation
of command in Vietnam, and the short tours that the men had, do you feel like that had any impact on that?
Yeah, I did.
I did the same thing.
I had a year there and a year back here, and I went back over for another year.
I really felt that the normal soldier, meaning the privates and the specialists, and you running out of tape?
Yeah, privates and specialists and the people that are actually fighting.
A year is a long time we fight out in the trees.
And they would try to pull them in every two or three months and what have you and give them some type of relax and recuperation.
But we were having commanders who were a commander or a staff officer for six months, then go out and be a commander for six months.

and I didn't think that worked and I think the military probably thought it didn't work either because I think near the end they were cutting that out but the being a commander just for six months it's hard to get your feet on the ground even in civilian life to do something for six months and go do something else for six months time you learn how to do it you're gone and I felt in the officer wise on different staff positions and command positions
If you're going to put him over there as commander, put him over there for the full tour, not just six months.
But the soldier, the private on the ground, I don't think he could take it for a year of steady out in the jungle fighting.
Some didn't.
Did you believe, as you hinted before, and like Curtis LeMay of the Strategic Air Command, that bombing escalation was the way to win the war?
Yeah, I felt that way.
that if you got their supplies from the Ho Chi Minh Trail and you took the war home to their homeland, then you would win.
We did the same thing in World War II.
We bombed certain areas of Europe off the face of the earth.
I've been to them now, and you would never know it, but areas like Mannheim, Germany, and Worms, Germany, and Dusseldorf and a few of those places, it was just leveled.

I think we showed using the atomic bomb, Nagasaki and Hiroshima, that when you unleash that type of firepower, I'm not saying we should have dropped the atomic bomb in Vietnam, but you leash a lot of firepower on the enemy, they may think twice about whether they want to continue this.
How did the U.S. military plan to win the hearts and minds of the people through destruction?
Yeah.
When you think about that, we used to joke about it somewhat, that how do you, just what you were saying, how do you win the hearts and minds of the people by killing them?

When you brought in your forces to attack certain areas in the South, and that's what you were doing because you were fighting the war in the South, if you had approval from the South Vietnamese government or from the regional area,
to do bombing runs, and it happened to be some friendly Vietnamese families in there, you really don't win much when you blow them up.

And when you go into their homes and what have you and burn them down, whether you might think they're, or you've got reports that they were sympathizers or not, and you cause this destruction, it was awful hard to win the hearts and minds
and some of the things we did, but again here you had so many problems of identifying who were the players.
Everybody looked alike, everybody wore the same uniform to speak of.
During the day this individual you might know was a real top-notch South Vietnamese supporter, a Nike, the Griller, against you.
You had children on the road that would wave at you during the day and at night throw a grenade in your vehicle.
So it was awful hard to identify the players.
And any time you got a war, some innocent people were going to get killed.
I find it interesting that you were an advisor with an entire battalion with you.
Did you ever have any briefings, both in your first or maybe your second term, on ways to
We were sent to school prior to going to Vietnam.
The sergeant, who I didn't know until I got over there, but he had attended special courses that were conducted at Fort Benning, Georgia.
I went to a special officer's course at Fort Benning.
Because of things moving along, they didn't teach us much how to speak the language over there.
We were given an interpreter.
But I lucked out.
The individual I was advising spoke very good English.
So we got along very well.
For that matter, we would use the same communications.
In some cases, I'd get up in the helicopter and talk to him back and forth on the ground.
And so we had no problems in communication.
Yeah, I did go to school for about a month on how to go in and how to try
I don't know how much you know about Orientals, but you can never tell them anything.
You cannot tell an Oriental to do anything and expect it to be done.
You have to talk to them.
And I speak from experience, since I have adopted two Koreans.
You can never tell them anything.
You have to make them think it's their idea.
So yes, we had some problems trying to win the hearts and minds of the people.
You try to do it with good works.
You had a lot of American civilians over there that were from the State Department, what have you, of coming in with different teams to assist them in sanitation, to assist them in agricultural.
I worked in this battalion at night.
I worked on certain nights as an instructor trying to teach the kids how to speak English.
getting funds to build schools for them.

We were receiving in from our American ships equipment, and the ships had what's called dunnage aborted boards and big two-by-fours and logging and what have you that helped the ship keep the equipment in one place as it was coming across, and they would take all this stuff and throw it up on the dock.
We worked out a deal where we could pick some of this stuff up and we'd build a school for them.
I said, we didn't build it.
The sergeant and I didn't build it.
But we got the equipment.
They picked it up.
They did the work.
And all this was trying to help them in the sanitation and the schooling and what have you.
And I thought it did some good.
The people that you got to know and the people that you worked with, I felt we did real well with.
But the people that were on the borderline
It was awful hard.
Sometimes they just were looking for a handout and forget the rest of it.
Um, moving on to some other things, some other aspects, um, do you feel Lyndon Johnson's refusal to call on reserve troops to stay?
You mean, um... Later in the year.
I don't know.
I don't know what President Johnson had in mind.
I don't know if we could have done any more with any more troops over there.
We had so many people running around over there now.
I still fall back on the same thing that you just said a few minutes ago about General May.
I thought General May was right in what he was trying to say was carry the war.
That's what it was.
To the north.
through the American Air Force, and you can have as many people as you want.
You need to have as many guns as you want, as many tanks as you want, but as long as you stay fighting in one little area, it could go on forever, which it did.
What would you like to say?
No, that's good.
Could you please describe your second tour of duty, specifically in Vietnam and Hawaii?
Okay.
The second tour I had, I left Vietnam in 1968, April of 1968, and I was reassigned that time to Berlin, Germany, as a battalion executive officer.

and i served over there about a year and a half of a three-year tour by the way and i got sent back to vietnam that's the way it was going for us infantry types you would stay about a year or so somewhere and then go back again and the second time i went back over and i have some background in logistics and i had no idea what i was doing i was just being sent back to vietnam again and when i got into
The center, where all the replacements come in, they said, well, you're going up to the 101st Airborne, which was located up around Hue, Vietnam.
Now, the 101st at that time had changed over and became air mobile, which we were, for the most part, with helicopters.
You had some ground crews, but for the most part, we were moving from point A to point B by helicopters.
Very few trucks.
So I went up there, and I
found out that I was the operation officer for the 101st Airborne Division Support Command.

Support Command means just what it means, is that its responsibility was not really the fighting of anything, but supporting the soldiers, the battalions and divisions that were out in the field carrying on the war.
My job as operation officer was twofold.
And this is where I got in this six-month deal.
The first six months, I was in charge of a forward service support company, and I'll come back to that and tell you about that.
And the second six months, I went back as the operation officer itself for the division, the support command operation.
The first six months was something like a company commander of a unit that was assigned to one of the battalions,
We had under us a helicopter pad.
We had a food storage facility.
We had water, fuel.
We had responsibility for coordination for all air traffic of supplies for that battalion or division, whatever they be.
In my case, I was assigned with a
I had three battalions who were taken care of.
And whenever they went into combat or normal everyday operation, we were responsible for providing them the support.
And you'd go to staff meetings and find out what they wanted and make sure that everything got from point A to point B for them.
I did that for six months, and then I went back to our division headquarters.
The first six months was in a place called Fubat, and it had a MASH hospital in that area, and we were responsible for that.

not not for the dust off helicopters but just to make sure that they had their supplies to get from point a to point b when when the wounded were called or when they called for helicopters for wounded we didn't do anything in that area we just made sure that the helicopters themselves got their fuel and all that and the pilot had a place to live and so but anyway uh the second six months i went back and became a i say went back to this was a division headquarters
I was the operation officer for the entire division, which was responsibility for all these forward service support companies, which were about four of them.
And then we were also responsible for some of the security for the Camp Eagle, which was division headquarters.
So in one case, I was there out in the field doing the commander of one of the small units, and then the second time, or the

the next six months I was in charge of all these little outfits company outfits to coordinate everybody's work and for the most part I never really got involved in anything like fighting like I got in the first time I was dealing with the American units all the time and we were always on the radio or on the phone or we were making sure supplies got from point a to point b and

I didn't hardly even see any Vietnamese soldiers, or we were just, I was so involved in supplies and resupplying and what have you that I could have been anywhere and not even know the war was going on unless somebody was shooting at me, because I was not really involved in the tactics end of it.
I was just involved in getting the supplies to whoever wanted them.
I'm not certain if you could answer this,
Do you know what was responsible for the most casualties by the Vietnamese attacks?
What caused their casualties?
You mean the North Vietnamese attacks on the Americans?
Right.
Oh, no, I don't know any one single thing that caused the most casualties.
I know that they were

A lot of the American soldiers or the Vietnamese have a, South Vietnamese had a weird feeling when you start walking through the jungles because they had different types of traps and what they called pungy sticks which is a sharp stick with poison on them of some sort and they had different type of holes that you'd fall into and like cut you in two with different type of steel wires and whatever.
I don't think there's any one thing that you can say that killed more Americans or more Vietnamese than anything else.
It was a combination of everything.
Were there ever any standing orders that you were aware that when evacuating, when you did that?
where helicopters were refused to go?
Or was it just an individual basis in a combat situation that you couldn't come to their relief, to take out the relief?
You're talking about American or South Vietnamese?
American.
No, I've never heard of any.
I've known a lot of American and also South Vietnamese helicopter pilots, and they were a dedicated bunch.
I've seen them go in
or been told about it or a known pilot that had gone in where they were told not to go in because probably they would not have got out.
Or they've gone into places where it was probably the chances of getting out was almost nil when they got in and got back out again.
I think it was just the opposite.
I don't know of any officer that ever refused to go in and take anybody out.
